docs.lead_paragraph: Heart experts would like doctors and patients to stop focusing just on bad cholesterol and start thinking about ''metabolic syndrome,'' a cluster of warning signs that new research shows is far more accurate in predicting the risk of diabetes and heart disease. Under recently revised and simplified guidelines, patients are considered to have metabolic syndrome if they have three of the following five conditions: abdominal obesity; high levels of trigyclerides, a fatlike substance in the blood; low levels of good cholesterol; high blood sugar levels; and high blood pressure.
docs.abstract: Glasgow (Scotland) Royal Infirmary researchers publish data in American Heart Association journal Circulation that helps identify metabolic syndrome and demonstrate appropriate guidelines for tackling array of warning signs; metabolic syndrome is diagnosed when three of five conditions--such as abdominal obesity, high levels of triglycerides, low levels of good cholesterol, high blood sugar and high blood pressure--are present; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Heart experts would like doctors and patients to stop focusing just on bad cholesterol and start thinking about ''metabolic syndrome,'' a cluster of warning signs that new research shows is far more accurate in predicting the risk of diabetes and...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Ryan's Vitiligo,'' by Cynthia May, with illustrations by Shannon Nelson. Spartan Graphics, $5. ''Hi, I'm Ryan. This is a story about what started happening to me when I was 8 years old. I wish I could tell you that this is all make believe, but it's real.''

headline.main: A Guide to Skin Disease Through the Eyes of a Boy

docs.abstract: Cynthia May's book Ryan's Vitiligo is intended to provide empathetic comfort for children suffering from unconcealable skin disorder; Ryan's diagnosis, treatments and final acceptance of his vitiligo discussed;photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''Ryan's Vitiligo,'' by Cynthia May, with illustrations by Shannon Nelson. Spartan Graphics, $5.      ''Hi, I'm Ryan. This is a story about what started happening to me when I was 8 years old. I wish I could tell you that this is all make believe,...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Katie Couric had an on-air colonoscopy, America followed her example: a study released yesterday found that rates of the screening for colon cancer jumped by more than 20 percent. The study's lead author, Dr. A. Mark Fendrick of the University of Michigan, said screening rates often rose after celebrities revealed their illness, like President Ronald Reagan's colon cancer or Magic Johnson's infection with H.I.V.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researcher Dr A Mark Fendrick reports 20% rise in colonoscopies across America following Katie Couric's on-air screening; study polled group of 400 endoscopists and health plan records of 44,000 members over nine-month period; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: When Katie Couric had an on-air colonoscopy, America followed her example: a study released yesterday found that rates of the screening for colon cancer jumped by more than 20 percent.     The study's lead author, Dr. A. Mark Fendrick of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not just that some people don't know their own strength. It may be that nobody does. Researchers have found that people routinely believe they are exerting less force than they really are. The findings, which appear in the current issue of the journal Science, lend insight into the nature of human movement.

headline.main: You May Be Hercules; You Just Don't Know It

docs.abstract: Dr Sukhwinder S Shergill, lead author of study published in journal Science, holds that normal neural processing often leads to escalation of conflicts; contends that tests reveal that humans are able to fairly accurately gauge impact of blow they receive but have poor concept of force they are using, consequently hitting back harder than they are hit (S)
docs.snippet: It is not just that some people don't know their own strength. It may be that nobody does.    Researchers have found that people routinely believe they are exerting less force than they really are. The findings, which appear in the current issue of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors have reported the first known case of fraternal twins who shared a single placenta in the womb. The researchers have suggested that this unique form of twinning may have come about as a result of in vitro fertilization. The twins, a boy and a girl, are now 2 years old and ''normal and healthy,'' said Dr. Vivienne L. Souter, a geneticist who described them in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: A First: Fraternal Twins, One Placenta

docs.abstract: Dr Vivienne L Souter describes in New England Journal of Medicine first known case of fraternal twins born sharing same placenta; boy and girl are now two and carry both male and female blood; conceived through in vitro fertilization, some doctors speculate embryo growth for several days in laboratory environment may have caused shells of blastocysts to fuse and mother's body to respond by producing only one placenta (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors have reported the first known case of fraternal twins who shared a single placenta in the womb. The researchers have suggested that this unique form of twinning may have come about as a result of in vitro fertilization.    The twins, a boy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the many mysteries surrounding multiple sclerosis, one of the most painful is what to expect after a diagnosis. Some people with similar brain scan findings will go years before having new bouts, while in others the disease progresses with daunting swiftness. Now a new study, published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine, suggests that tests for two kinds of antibodies can predict which group new patients fall into. The antibodies appear to reflect an immune system attack against proteins that help protect nerve tissue.
docs.abstract: Austrian researchers' study, published in New England Journal of Medicine, finds that progression of multiple sclerosis can be marked by presence of two antibodies; contends that 95% of multiple sclerosis patients with both antibodies show disease symptoms or progression within seven and half months; information will help doctors target those needing aggressive treatment programs (S)
docs.snippet: Of the many mysteries surrounding multiple sclerosis, one of the most painful is what to expect after a diagnosis. Some people with similar brain scan findings will go years before having new bouts, while in others the disease progresses with...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes medicines prescribed for one disorder will help patients with a different one. In today's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine, two studies followed up on such promising signs; one found them to be borne out, while the other did not. One looked at the effect of a class of blood pressure drugs called ACE inhibitors on people with diabetes.
docs.abstract: Dutch researchers study, published in Annals of Internal Medicine, finds that ACE inhibitors, typically prescribed for high blood pressure, resulted in significant reductions in kidney damaging albumin when given to patients with diabetes; alleged connection between statins, used primarily to treat high cholesterol, and prevention or control of osteoporosis is dispelled by evidence collected in database of Women's Health Initiative observational study and also published in Annals of Internal Medicine; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Sometimes medicines prescribed for one disorder will help patients with a different one. In today's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine, two studies followed up on such promising signs; one found them to be borne out, while the other did not.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: No branch of medicine intersects with politics more than public health. Not surprisingly, the two areas often clash, particularly when health issues bear on economics, like SARS and tobacco use. Few know this interplay better than Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, a physician and Harvard-trained public health specialist, who next week ends her five-year term as director general of the World Health Organization here.

headline.main: An Era Ends, Many Missions Accomplished

docs.abstract: World Health Organization's director general Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland leaves office next week after one five-year term; faced with emergence of SARS and fueled by her determination to eradicate polio, make drugs accessible to poor and control worldwide use of tobacco, Brundtland acknowledges organization is in better place to effect change than when she began in 1998; her background is given and some success stories discussed, including Framework Convention on Tobacco Control; effective handling of SARS epidemic by WHO, under leadership of Brundtland, is credited with sparking renewed collaborative efforts between nations to proactively fight disease; Dr Jong Wook Lee will be her successor as director general; photo (M)
docs.snippet: No branch of medicine intersects with politics more than public health. Not surprisingly, the two areas often clash, particularly when health issues bear on economics, like SARS and tobacco use.    Few know this interplay better than Dr. Gro Harlem...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''H'' stands for ''high'' -- that's how to remember which of your cholesterol readings should be as high as you can get it: H.D.L.-C. Known as the good cholesterol, it is the common designation for high-density lipoprotein cholesterol. It is the cholesterol-carrying protein in your blood that acts like arterial Drano, helping to keep critical blood vessels from clogging up with circulation-impeding deposits.

headline.main: Cholesterol: When It's Good, It's Very, Very Good

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses importance of having good cholesterol and how to get it; Dr Michael Miller, University of Maryland Medical Center for Preventive Cardiology director, explains that low levels of good cholesterol are considered stronger indicator of coronary heart disease than high levels of bad cholesterol; diet, exercise and moderate use of alcohol have all been shown to effect good cholesterol; several heart-protective and good cholesterol-raising drugs are mentioned; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: ''H'' stands for ''high'' -- that's how to remember which of your cholesterol readings should be as high as you can get it: H.D.L.-C. Known as the good cholesterol, it is the common designation for high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.    It is the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The patient couldn't tell me what was wrong, and neither could his 80-year-old mother. He had been lying on the sofa for weeks, she said, and he wouldn't get up. Sloth was a sin, but was it a reason to be admitted to the hospital?
docs.abstract: Cases article describes middle age man with symptoms resembling chronic depression, but who was diagnosed with extreme hypothyroidism, which effects memory, physical energy and reflexes; patient's mother finds empty bottle of thyroid hormone after he is diagnosed; need for individuals to carry list of medications with them noted (M)
docs.snippet: The patient couldn't tell me what was wrong, and neither could his 80-year-old mother. He had been lying on the sofa for weeks, she said, and he wouldn't get up.    Sloth was a sin, but was it a reason to be admitted to the hospital?
